diagnoses.name: Viral pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pericardium caused by a viral infection, often presenting with fever, sharp chest pain, and, in some cases, pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organs including the skin, joints, kidneys (proteinuria), brain (seizures), and heart (pericarditis and pericardial effusion).

diagnoses.name: Uremic pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pericardium due to accumulation of uremic toxins, seen in patients with severe chronic kidney disease, potentially leading to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of untreated or inadequately treated strep throat, potentially leading to fever, pericarditis, and carditis.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculous pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pericardium caused by tuberculosis infection, may present with fever, night sweats, and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Infection of the pericardium by bacteria, presenting with acute onset of fever, chest pain, and potentially leading to pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Pericarditis resulting from an autoimmune response, often associated with systemic autoimmune disorders, can present with acute chest pain, fever, and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Neoplastic pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Pericarditis caused by cancerous processes either from direct invasion of the pericardium or as a paraneoplastic syndrome, potentially presenting with pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced lupus pericarditis
diagnoses.description: A form of lupus erythematosus induced by certain medications, which can include symptoms such as pericarditis, fever, and in some cases, proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Mixed connective tissue disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that may exhibit features of lupus, scleroderma, and myositis, with possible manifestations including pericarditis, fever, and renal involvement.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, considering a broader differential)
Vitamin Deficiencies (e.g., Vitamin B12, Vitamin C deficiency)
Hashimoto's Thyroiditis with fluctuating thyroid function
Bleeding Disorders such as von Willebrand Disease
Chronic Inflammatory Diseases leading to secondary anemia
Connective Tissue Disorders like Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
Secondary Immunodeficiency (due to medication or disease)

diagnoses.reasoning: Anxiety can manifest with a variety of physical symptoms such as pseudoseizures, difficulty concentrating, and flushing.
Hyperthermia and flushing can be signs of heat exhaustion or heat stroke.
While pseudoseizures are non-epileptic, they can sometimes be mistaken for epilepsy; difficulty concentrating can also be a postictal symptom.
Otis externa indicates an ear infection, which can cause fever (hyperthermia) and general malaise, potentially leading to difficulty concentrating.
This condition can cause symptoms like flushing and hyperthermia due to improper regulation of the autonomic nervous system.
Can lead to a wide variety of symptoms including difficulty concentrating (often described as 'fibro fog'), pseudoseizures, and other somatic symptoms.
Pseudoseizures are a common symptom in somatoform disorders, as are other physical symptoms without a clear organic cause.
Substance use can lead to a variety of symptoms including difficulty concentrating, pseudoseizures (especially during withdrawal), hyperthermia, and flushing.
Hyperthyroidism can cause symptoms such as difficulty concentrating, hyperthermia, and flushing.
Certain types of neuroendocrine tumors, like carcinoid tumors, can cause flushing and hyperthermia among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth.

diagnoses.name: Angioedema
diagnoses.description: An area of swelling of the lower layer of skin and tissue just under the skin or mucous membranes.
common_symptoms: swelling in the eyes and lips
sometimes swelling of the hands, feet, and throat

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: An intestinal disorder causing pain in the belly, gas, diarrhea, and constipation.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing itchy, watery eyes, sneezing, and other similar symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder that causes severe swelling, typically around the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airway.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A digestive disease in which stomach acid or bile irritates the food pipe lining.
common_symptoms: regurgitation of food or sour liquid
feeling of a lump in your throat

diagnoses.name: Dry Eye Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when your tears aren't able to provide adequate lubrication for your eyes.
common_symptoms: a stinging, burning or scratchy sensation in your eyes
stringy mucus in or around your eyes
a sensation of having something in your eyes

diagnoses.name: Dental Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that can form inside the teeth, in the gums, or in the bone that holds the teeth in place.
common_symptoms: sensitivity to hot and cold temperatures
sensitivity to the pressure of chewing or biting
swelling in your face or cheek
tender, swollen lymph nodes under your jaw or in your neck
sudden rush of foul-smelling and foul-tasting, salty fluid in your mouth and pain relief, if the abscess ruptures

diagnoses.description: An anxiety disorder characterized by chronic anxiety, exaggerated worry, and tension, even when there is little or nothing to provoke it.
A rare genetic condition causing tumors and cysts to grow in the brain, spine, and eyes, which may include hemangioblastomas (a type of angiomata).
A type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow, characterized by the overproduction of abnormal white blood cells. It can lead to bone pain and lymphadenopathy.
A group of blood cancers that develop from lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell). It often causes lymphadenopathy and can sometimes cause bone pain.
A disorder characterized by the accumulation of mast cells in the skin, bone marrow, and internal organs. Skin manifestations include angiomata-like lesions.
A cancer of plasma cells that causes cancer cells to accumulate in the bone marrow, leading to bone pain and lesions.
An anxiety disorder marked by recurrent panic attacks that are unexpected and cause significant worry or behavioral changes.
An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. It can cause lymphadenopathy.
Occurs when one or more of the parathyroid glands become overactive. It can lead to bone pain due to high levels of calcium in the blood.
A rare disorder that involves an overgrowth of cells in the body's lymph nodes, leading to lymphadenopathy.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reaction
diagnoses.reasoning: Symptoms such as angioedema, dermatographism, and dyspnea can be indicative of various types of allergic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.reasoning: Severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can lead to angioedema, dyspnea, and dermatographism.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.reasoning: MCAS can cause a wide range of symptoms, including dermatographism, angioedema, and dyspnea, due to inappropriate mast cell activation.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Idiopathic Urticaria
diagnoses.reasoning: This condition, characterized by the development of hives and angioedema, can also lead to dermatographism.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: A disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that can form as nodules in multiple organs, including the lymph nodes (lymphadenitis) and lungs (leading to dyspnea), though pulmonary function tests might remain normal in early or mild cases.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause lymphadenitis, dyspnea, and in some cases skin manifestations that might resemble dermatographism.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.reasoning: A genetic disorder that can cause recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema), which is one of the symptoms listed.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Cancer of the lymphatic system can present with lymphadenitis and could potentially lead to symptoms such as dyspnea if it involves the thoracic region.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it can lead to lymphadenitis, and in some cases, patients may experience dyspnea, especially if there is a complication like splenic enlargement.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: A disorder characterized by high counts of eosinophils in the blood and/or tissues, which can cause dermatological conditions including dermatographism, as well as dyspnea and potentially lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses: Squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Toxic exposure (e.g., chemical or plant allergies)
Bacterial Infections (e.g., Salmonella, E. coli, Shigella)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Acute urinary retention causing overflow incontinence
Neurogenic shock due to spinal cord injury
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Brain Tumors (e.g., acoustic neuroma or other tumors affecting the cerebellum or brainstem)
Infectious Diseases (specific infections might lead to such a symptom constellation and should be ruled out depending on epidemiological factors)
Psychiatric manifestation of systemic autoimmune diseases
